Summary Note:
Robert Pierre Robin and the RM crossed paths at a tech conference in Paris. They attended several keynote sessions together and realized they had a shared vision for the future of technology investments.
Robert Pierre Robin is a 47 year old Industry Leader from France. He has a diverse background, having worked in various capacities and gained extensive knowledge in the field.
Julius Baer's exceptional client service and bespoke financial solutions were the main reasons he decided to join.
Family Background: Robert Pierre Robin has been happily married to Chloé since 2007. They do not have any children.
Education Background:
Robert completed his secondary education at Lycée Fustel de Coulanges in 1995.
Robert attended University of Toulouse and graduated in 2000.
Occupation History:
Robert Pierre Robin is a 47 year old Industry Leader from France.
At Ipsen S.A., Robert Pierre Robin held the position of Research Scientist from 2002 to 2005, developing essential skills in the field.
In 2005, he moved to Cellectis S.A. to work as a Biotech Startup Founder, applying his knowledge to achieve outstanding performance.
At Transgene S.A., he worked as a CEO from 2008 to 2009, focusing on strategic initiatives and team collaboration.
After 7 years of dedication, he assumed the role of Venture Capitalist at Cellectis S.A. in 2011, spearheading high-profile projects and mentoring junior colleagues.
Since joining Sanofi S.A. as a Industry Leader in 2017, he has established himself as a respected authority, fostering collaboration and pushing boundaries to achieve groundbreaking results.
Wealth Summary:
While working, he saved 350000 EUR, which he used to build a diversified investment portfolio.
He has townhouse located in Brest, worth 2080000 EUR.

In 2008, he received an inheritance of 4590000 EUR from his late grandfather, who was a prominent Venture Capitalist, and has since invested it in various assets.
Client Summary: In conclusion, we are confident in the client's financial stability and future prospects.
